channel.title: Nameserver question
channel.description:
I'm hosting a nameserver on my server. My registrar requires the address to the nameserver to be an hostname, not an IP.
Which hostname should I be using as the nameserver? The only hostnames which point to my server are the one assigned by my ISP ( host12-123-12-123.range12-123.btcentralplus.com ), and my DynDNS hostname ( something.ath.cx ).
Which one of these should I be using, or doesn't it matter? Which hostname should I use for all the definitions in the bind9 config? I'd rather use the DynDNS hostname because the one assigned by my ISP is liable to change.
SHIT SHOULD I EVEN BE USING BIND FOR A PUBLIC DOMAINS NAMESERVER? IS IT JUST FOR INTERNAL DNS?

item.title: Nameserver question
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

I don’t understand.

I have two hostnames pointing to my IP. I have one from DynDns and an automatically assigned one from my ISP. I tried setting up bind but it just isn’t working, and I’m positive I’ve done everything right. The only thing I was concerned about was the actual hostname the nameserver should be.

Say my domain is bacon.com. 123-REG allows full DNS control, so I could create a subdomain ns1.bacon.com which would point to my IP. However, once I change the nameservers from 123-REG’s address to my own, the DNS settings on my account no longer have any meaning. Correct?

I can’t exactly set the nameservers to ns1.bacon.com and ns2.bacon.com if the rules which map these addresses to my IP aren’t being accessed.

Switching registrars isn’t an option, because I’ve obviously already bought the domain and I’m not paying to have it transferred.

I’m not sure why I would need to find an alternative host. What alternatives were you thinking of? I host myself because it gives me much more freedom and I don’t have to pay rental fees.
